item.title:
A war in Ukraine would have terrible consequences, including for Russia. It would destabilise the global order and could even prove Vladimir Putin’s undoing.
Our cover this week ⬇️
Society bombards us with instructions to be happier, fitter and richer. Why have we become so dissatisfied with being ordinary? https://t.co/d5lpPUc2MQ
Vladimir Putin may choose to strike Ukraine between the end of the Winter Olympics on February 20th and the spring thaw https://t.co/3fMXOiGhzV

In the 1950s and 1960s the CIA undertook a covert operation to investigate whether people could be brainwashed and controlled with drugs and hypnosis. Find out how they did it on “Checks and Balance” https://t.co/PaGofiWNJ7 https://t.co/UJa6c5BUW0
War with Ukraine poses huge risks for the fortunes of Russia’s oligarchs, the national mood and the Russian economy. It is impossible to know if Vladimir Putin cares https://t.co/TgC76HTSkh

Eliminating meat production would change landscapes, ways of life and relationships with animals and food shaped over millennia—and parts of economies linked to them, including tourism https://t.co/dvQHrVjRYG
Evidence-based decisions are replacing moral panic https://t.co/Qm38u5b5zQ
Kremlin officials have suggested that if NATO does not stop protecting countries close to Russia, Russia might deploy forces to Venezuela https://t.co/WaxA6PqTRW

When the Soviet Union collapsed in 1991, ethnic Kazakhs were just under 40% of the population and Russians were 37%. Ethnic Kazakhs are now 70% of a population of 19m and ethnic Russians are only 18% https://t.co/wxLY4V58aE
Users report an increased sense of connection, a decrease in anxiety and a reduction in depressive symptoms https://t.co/tiQr5iv9JA
“We’re both deeply disappointed with the human experiment”—what does Brian Cox have in common with Logan Roy, the patriarch he plays in “Succession”? https://t.co/4dvCRWt1a7 https://t.co/ncbiW6Cs8U
In the absence of alcohol, sweet treats unite the Middle East https://t.co/ujN10RjQ16
The FDA has hailed psilocybin—the psychoactive compound in “magic mushrooms”—as a “breakthrough therapy” in treating severe depression https://t.co/d7tA2ROa69
What would "veganuary" for everyone, all year round, look like from space? I had a look at the numbers, and found that it could free up roughly 1/3 of all habitable land. https://t.co/pwuUmmGb1Z
In Argentina, annual inflation is above 50%. This is eroding the real value of some social spending https://t.co/KCVT34PkiJ
America’s extreme dominance in military power is “madness” and “a substantial contribution to environmental destruction”, he wrote for The Economist in September https://t.co/791ltCEv92
Russians have an increasingly positive attitude towards Ukraine. A war in which Ukrainians and young Russians die in their thousands would be massively unpopular https://t.co/yq1ous58W6
Even a diet avoiding only meat from cattle and sheep would cut land use in half https://t.co/XjoHL5OteG
Vladimir Putin lacks the resources to turn Venezuela into a successful satellite. Nonetheless, Russia’s role in Latin America is troubling https://t.co/rHrmNUC39c
Ethiopia's Tigray region is getting only a fraction of the food needed to keep its 6m inhabitants alive, hardly any fuel and no medical supplies at all https://t.co/4WJJAL0gGP

A war in Ukraine would have terrible consequences, including for Russia. It would destabilise the global order and could even prove Vladimir Putin’s undoing.
Our cover this week ⬇️
Society bombards us with instructions to be happier, fitter and richer. Why have we become so dissatisfied with being ordinary? https://t.co/SoARaipEgx
Psychedelic drugs show tremendous promise. Initiatives like Oregon’s are essential if they are to realise their therapeutic potential https://t.co/nb6cvVb57k
Why is Putin so afraid of young people? https://t.co/GO5iTVNuCW
Russia’s efforts to stop NATO’s eastward expansion are more likely to reunite the alliance and push other countries into joining https://t.co/MPKGNWIjP3
He saw Buddhism as a raft that could lift Vietnam, a country ferociously fought over, and save it https://t.co/4VQhND9h6M

A war in Ukraine would have terrible consequences, including for Russia. It would destabilise the global order and could even prove Vladimir Putin’s undoing.
Our cover this week ⬇️

In his new book, “Davos Man”, @petersgoodman argues that the mega-rich’s pursuit of wealth has undermined society’s capacity to deal with crises and left the world in its present troubled state https://t.co/3bS0RcDEDd
Ukraine is a direct affront to Vladimir Putin’s authoritarian Russia. He may see war as essential to his survival https://t.co/p7VWEeWMjI
His aim was peace and his motivation was compassion, a wish to understand and lighten the suffering of others https://t.co/AVlMtoJyWT
Rhinos were the only recorded dispersers of 35% of the large-fruited species found in the regions where data were available https://t.co/lUkdMCUczv
Studies are showing that psychedelic drugs have potential in treating several thorny mental-health problems https://t.co/F0jR6j8waR
Ukraine lacks proper air defence and its armed forces are weak. Russia’s military could drive into Kyiv with little resistance https://t.co/ktMtjCSWQf
Psilocybin is not intended to replace conventional therapies for depression, but to sit alongside them https://t.co/eCdiVo0FrU
Brizilian Portuguese appears to have produced more, and more varied, words than its European counterpart https://t.co/nFkz1VWj8L

Psilocybin is not a cure-all; and Oregon’s policies may need to be tweaked. But the state’s voters deserve praise for the sort of clear-headed sense of proportion too long absent from American drug policy https://t.co/e1NBOOM534
Psychedelics seem to help with the treatment of depression, addiction and PTSD. Precisely how they work is unclear, so more research is needed https://t.co/68LdJ0k4Bg
Society bombards us with instructions to be happier, fitter and richer. Why have we become so dissatisfied with being ordinary? https://t.co/Pi6IKSZG0Y
Vladimir Putin may have lost sight of the bigger picture—or think he sees a bigger picture than anyone else https://t.co/0e0NswvIPk
This week’s cartoon from KAL: https://t.co/G2Ehb0UscY
America’s drugs regulator may approve MDMA for treating PTSD as early as next year https://t.co/eJEiDPkCm3
Countries do not redraw others’ borders by force. A successful Russian invasion of Ukraine would rip up that norm https://t.co/hPOQnTD18r
Brazil’s government is presiding over a return to fiscal incontinence, rising inflation, high interest rates and low growth https://t.co/8Fc6PUXQec
Like all populists, Recep Tayyip Erdogan ascribes setbacks to plots by his enemies https://t.co/A7C7yfz79b
Oregonians will soon be able to avail themselves of therapy for depression using psilocybin, the psychoactive compound in “magic mushrooms” https://t.co/B97guCPOz2
All species of rhinoceros are in trouble, as poachers kill them to take their horns. But Sumatran rhinos are in extremis https://t.co/NhiutyNoOm

Last March I saw the fun word "lambe-lambe" used to describe a poster campaign. Thus began a quest to learn why "reduplication" (words like "corre-corre" and "pula-pula") is so common in Brazil. Along the way, I discovered "lepo-lepo." For @TheEconomist 🧵https://t.co/iQYxFnTjR2

Russia is the world’s biggest exporter of natural gas, and the second-largest exporter of oil. It supplies nearly a tenth of the aluminium and copper, and produces 43% of palladium. It is also the largest exporter of wheat https://t.co/YVvJPzBwHh

In this week's @TheEconomist: my 10-page Technology Quarterly on hiding vs finding in warfare: the impact of more sensors, better sensors & better-connected sensors. It ranges from synthetic aperture radar, to anti-submarine warfare, to modern deception. https://t.co/TI0BO30Ltn https://t.co/F415mhxTib
Companies based in rich countries often facilitate corruption abroad https://t.co/ARYtZkvU8S
